clusters.title: Communities react in anger after MotoGP moved from Phillip Island to Adelaide
clusters.neutral_headline: Communities react in anger after MotoGP moved from Phillip Island to Adelaide
bullet_summary: Reported by The Age, 9News, ABC Sport

items.title: Communities react in anger after MotoGP moved from Phillip Island to Adelaide
items.standfirst: Phillip Island has lost the Australian MotoGP after the Victorian Government failed to secure a new contract, infuriating race fans and passionate locals.
items.content: Phillip Island has lost the Australian MotoGP after the Victorian Government failed to secure a new contract, infuriating race fans and passionate locals.

items.title: Phillip Island community 'in mourning' after MotoGP moves to Adelaide
items.standfirst: "It's a big loss for us, but it's a huge loss for Victoria as well."
items.content: L ocal business owners on Victoria's Phillip Island have been left devastated by the news the MotoGP will move from its long-time home next year.Residents of the island are now "in mourning" following the announcement the three-day event will take place on a street circuit in Adelaide from 2027.Many are grappling over how the tourist spot will cope with the expected sharp drop in annual visitors.READ MORE: 'Disappointing': Victorian council admits drivers overpaid parking fines "We are currently a community in mourning," Bass Coast Mayor Rochelle Halstead said."We've had figures of $55 to 100 million economic benefit that this event brings to our local community."It's a big loss for us, but it's a huge loss for Victoria as well."The MotoGP brought 91,245 visitors to Phillip Island in 2025, an increase of over 11,000 attendees from the year prior. Phillip Island restauranteur Rosa Scarloto's Italian bistro Pino's Trattoria doubles as a shrine to the grand prix every year.She told 9News there are "no words" to describe the bitter blow she and other business owners have been dealt."I had no sleep last night – I did cry a little bit," Scarloto said.READ MORE: US increases military pressure on Iran ahead of key talks READ MORE: Billionaire says he was duped by 'world-class con man' Epstein "It's gonna be harder to say goodbye. I mean very, very, very hard."The MotoGP has roared around the Phillip Island circuit for more than 30 years. But it is not the first time the event has been taken away from the famous island community.The race spent six years during the 1990s in Sydney and locals fought to bring it back to Victoria.They vow to do it again once Adelaide's six-year contract is up.The Victorian government reportedly offered additional funding to keep the round of MotoGP on Phillip Island, but Adelaide secured a deal.The Grand Prix will make its final laps on Phillip Island in October.NEVER MISS A STORY: Get your breaking news and exclusive stories first by following us across all platforms.Download the 9NEWS App here via Apple and Google PlayMake 9News your preferred source on Google by ticking this box hereSign up to our breaking newsletter here

items.title: Racing champions unload over Phillip Island MotoGP loss to Adelaide
items.standfirst: Australian Motorcycle Grand Prix winner Wayne Gardner has lashed out at the Victorian government over the loss of the Phillip Island MotoGP, saying he has been left "disappointed" and "sad" by the decision.
items.content: Australian Motorcycle Grand Prix winner Wayne Gardner has lashed out at the Victorian government over the loss of the Phillip Island MotoGP, saying he has been left "disappointed" and "sad" by the decision.

items.content: An announcement on the future of the Australian Motorcycle Grand Prix is expected as soon as Thursday amid widespread speculation the event is set to shift to South Australia.

items.content: Victoria loses the rights to host the Australian Motorcycle Grand Prix, ending a three-decade association with the event.

items.title: Police investigate teen stabbing at Geelong shopping mall
items.standfirst: A 17-year-old boy has been taken to hospital with serious injuries after a suspected stabbing at the Market Square shopping centre in Geelong.
items.content: A 17-year-old boy has been taken to hospital with serious injuries after a suspected stabbing at the Market Square shopping centre in Geelong.

items.title: Teen seriously injured after stabbing at shopping centre near Melbourne
items.standfirst: A 17-year-old boy was found by police nearby with suspected stab wounds.
items.content: A teenage boy has been taken to hospital with serious injuries after he was stabbed at a shopping centre south-west of Melbourne.Police were called to a mall on Malop Street in Geelong around 3.30pm following Triple Zero calls about an assault.Two boys were seen fighting in the shopping centre surrounded by a group of bystanders, believed to be known to the pair, watching on. READ MORE: The stronger Aussie dollar looks here to stay – and it's not just travellers who are set to benefitA 17-year-old boy was found by police nearby with suspected stab wounds.He was taken to hospital with serious injuries.Police believe the other person involved, along with several bystanders, fled the scene and were last seen heading towards Yarra Street.A crime scene has been set up at the shopping centre and surrounding areas.Detectives are appealing for witnesses or anyone who may have filmed the altercation to please come forward.Anyone with information or anyone who may have witnessed the incident is urged to call Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000 or to submit a confidential report log onto www.crimestoppersvic.com.au.NEVER MISS A STORY: Get your breaking news and exclusive stories first by following us across all platforms.Download the 9NEWS App here via Apple and Google PlayMake 9News your preferred source on Google by ticking this box hereSign up to our breaking newsletter here

clusters.title: Extremist material allegedly found on man's phone after vehicle stop
clusters.neutral_headline: Extremist material allegedly found on man's phone after vehicle stop
bullet_summary: E xtremist material was allegedly found on a device seized during a traffic stop in Yagoona on December 31

items.title: Extremist material allegedly found on man's phone after vehicle stop
items.standfirst: A 31-year-old has been arrested a second time after police stopped and searched a vehicle in Yagoona and seized three mobile phones allegedly storing violent extremist material.
items.content: A 31-year-old has been arrested a second time after police stopped and searched a vehicle in Yagoona and seized three mobile phones allegedly storing violent extremist material.

items.title: Man charged with terrorism offence after traffic stop leads to raid on Sydney home
items.standfirst: E xtremist material was allegedly found on a device seized during a traffic stop in Yagoona on December 31.
items.content: A man has been charged with a terrorism offence after police analysed phones they seized during a traffic stop in Sydney's south-west.Officers searched a Toyota sedan on December 31 after pulling the car over on Dargan Street, Yagoona during a patrol of the area.Drugs, cash and three mobile phones were allegedly seized from the car.READ MORE: Ute found after man killed in horror head-on smash on major Queensland highwayA 31-year-old man was arrested and taken to Bankstown Police Station, where he was charged with supplying prohibited drugs, dealing with proceeds of crime under $5000 and using a non-compliant light vehicle. He was refused bail and faced court on January 1, where he was granted conditional bail.After examining the mobile phones, police allegedly unearthed violent extremist material.The discovery sparked a raid on a home in Bass Hill around 6am yesterday, where police seized more mobile phones, storage devices and a knife.READ MORE: Eight skiers found dead after US avalanche disasterA 31-year-old man was arrested and taken to Bansktown Police Station where he was charged with possessing violent extremist material and possessing or using a prohibited weapon without a permit.He was refused bail and appeared at Bankstown Local Court yesterday, where he was granted conditional bail to appear back in court on March 3.NEVER MISS A STORY: Get your breaking news and exclusive stories first by following us across all platforms.Download the 9NEWS App here via Apple and Google PlayMake 9News your preferred source on Google by ticking this box hereSign up to our breaking newsletter here
